A.ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
POLICIES

The High Desert Power Plant employees conduct ongoing inspections, testing, and replacement of the critical items in the aqueous ammonia systems.  The aqueous ammonia systems are monitored during (at least) daily rounds by a the High Desert Power Plant employee.  Typically, the High Desert Power Plant operators perform cursory facility inspections twice per shift, or six times per day.  Once identified, the High Desert Power Plant will fix or outsource any system deviation that is noted.  In any case, a record of the maintenance or work performed on the system is maintained by the Plant Supervisor.

The High Desert Power Plant has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Response Program section of the CalARP document, which is maintained at the facility and updated as necessary.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, aqueous ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year in conjunction with the Emergency Business Plan for the Victorville Fire 
Department .  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.

The High Desert Power Plant has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, Victorville Fire Department.  In the case of an aqueous ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of the High Desert Power Plant to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance o

f trained facility personnel).  The High Desert Power Plant also plans to contract with a private company to respond to any hazardous materials spills.

B.STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The High Desert Power Plant is located at 19000 Perimeter Road in Victorville, California.  The facility is situated Northwest of Interstate 15 off the D Street exit.  The immediate area is primarily industrial and rural.  The location for storing aqueous ammonia is in the southerly side of the property.  Ammonia sensors provide an alarm status to the control room which is manned 24 hours per day.  The High Desert Power Plant is a 750 MW unit that will be placed in commercial operation in May 2003.  The Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system scheduled completion date is in January 2003.  The facility uses 25% aqueous ammonia to catalytically reduce boiler flue gas nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions to elemental nitrogen and uses 19% aqueous ammonia to control the pH level of the condensate.

25% aqueous ammonia is used as a catalyst in the SCR system to assist in controlling the NOx emissions from the stack.  It is the only CalARP regulated substance on site.

The maximum inventory of 25% aqueous ammonia at the High Desert Power Plant is 39,300 gallons (308,702 pounds).

C.HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary (OAC1)

Scenario Description:   Release of the maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia that can be stored in a vessel (the liquid storage tank) - 39,300 gallons of 25% solution (308,702 pounds) in 10 minutes.  The liquid is assumed to leak into the concrete berm (passive mitigation) that surrounds the tank and then evaporate (rate = 90 lbs/min) at the highest daily temperature in the last three years.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F stability.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the t

oxic endpoint of 200 ppm in rural conditions.  This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

Note: The EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance reference tables yield the same result.

Alternative Release Result Summary (OAC2)

Scenario Description:   A release of aqueous ammonia resulting from the failure of a pressure relief valve to reseat.  The release rate of the ammonia vapor is calculated to be 4.6 pounds per minute.  The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters per second wind speed, and D stability.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in rural conditions.  This release does not reach off site and does not impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

D.ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The storage of aqueous ammonia at the High Desert Power Plant is governed by many safety features.  Much of the safety of the process is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the process.  For example, the High Desert Power Plant operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The CalARP Program included detailed hazard review to identify potential release scenarios, an analysis of the potential consequences associated with select release scenarios and a detailed seismic inspection of the aqueous ammonia process equipment.  In addition to the technical studies, the CalARP Program incorporated preventive programs such as detailed operating and maintenance procedures, incident investigation, training, auditing, and emergency response activities.  Finally, the aqueous ammonia processes are inspected by operators every two hours.
25% Aqueous Ammonia

The High Desert Power Plant maintains ti

ght control of its aqueous ammonia system through various process controls and monitors.  In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of aqueous ammonia, there are three mechanisms at the facility to minimize the impact:  1) a containment berm surrounding the aqueous ammonia tank sized to hold the entire contents of the tank, 2) an underground storage tank to contain any spills during the unloading process, and 3) both the storage tank and the underground containment tank are double-walled.  There are level controls on the storage tank to alert the operator to extreme level conditions. 
E.FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Both the aqueous ammonia treatment systems and the entire plant is new as of January 2003; therefore, there is no accident history to report.

F.EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The following summarizes the emergency response and notification procedures at the facility:

1.First call 911 on an internal/land line phone for the Victorville Fire Department and  police department.  The Victorville Fire Department can also be reached at (760) 955-5227 and the Victorville Police Department at (760) 241-2911. 

2.Contact either the Start-up Manager (Jim Hunt) or the Assistant Start-up Manager (Dale Bjorklund) immediately.  If they are not available, contact the Shift Supervisor or Safety Manager (John Herreth).

3.Call the Governor's Office of Emergency Services (OES) Warning Center 1-800-852-7550.

4.If additional help is required for an aqueous ammonia spill or leak, the facility can call Chemtrec - Manufacturing Chemists Association 1-800-424-9300.

5.If an aqueous ammonia release exceeds 1000 pounds or 135 gallons, call the National Response Center 1-800-424-8802 [24 hours, 7 days].

6.If serious injuries or harmful exposures to workers occurs, call the nearest Cal-OSHA Office at (909) 383-4321.

7.If an employee ingests aqueous ammonia, the Poison Control Center can be reached 24 hours per da

y at 1-800-342-9293.

8.Notify the local CalARP regulatory agency: Victorville Fire Department, Hazardous Materials Division at (760) 955-5229.

9.Call for assistance with chemical cleanup.  Do NOT use a regular vacuum truck, as they are not equipped to handle chemicals of this type.

10.Notify the Victor Valley Wastewater Reclamation Authority at (760) 246-8638.

11*.If any amount of aqueous ammonia is released into the storm drain, contact the Department of Fish and Game at their 24-hour hotline:  (888) DFG-CALTIP.

*The Department of Fish and Game receives a copy of the OES report; however if a significant amount is spilled into the storm drain, they would appreciate being contacted directly.

NOTE:There is an aqueous ammonia tote adjacent to the North Western side of the High Desert Power Plant belonging to the Victor Valley Wastewater Reclamation Authority.  In the event of an aqueous ammonia leak, be aware of the presence of another source and do not evacuate towards such source.

Emergency Procedures:

1.The Shift Supervisor will determine the extent of the release and proper notifications to make.

2.The Shift Supervisor will sound alarm to evacuate area.  Evacuation area must be upwind from ammonia vapors.

3.Evaluate hazards.  Barricade area with banner tape or cones to prevent access by other employees.

4.Ensure proper PPE; 

5.Ensure that staff responding to emergency have proper training.

Injured persons will be taken to the Designated Reporting Areas until professional medical assistance is available.  It is essential that any contaminated person is decontaminated as they leave the contamination zone, prior to entering the Designated Reporting Areas / Staging Areas.  Injured victims must be thoroughly decontaminated prior to receiving medical assistance.

The first aid kit will be taken to the Staging Areas or first aid/triage location established by High Desert Power Plant Start-up Manager.  All trained first aid personnel will report to first aid a

rea to assist the injured.

No rescue attempt will be made unless safe for the rescuer(s).  Any employee attempting a rescue may only do so if hazards are identified, employee has proper PPE & training, it has been confirmed by head count that an employee is unaccounted for and may still be in the facility and there is back up for the rescuer with equivalent training & PPE to assist.  

6.Contain spill or leak, if safe to do so, by closing valve, putting down absorbent, etc.

The emergency response plan is summarized in this section.  The plan is distributed to new hires who are required to read and sign a certification page.

G.PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Hazard Review provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the High Desert Power Plant located at 19000 Perimeter Road, Victorville, California 92394.  All recommendations are scheduled to be complete by January 3003.  A Seismic Assessment will be conducted upon completion of construction of the storage tank and associated piping, in November 2002.

R01:Incorporate response procedures for evacuation notification in the emergency response program (i.e. using the radios to evacuate or isolate the area).

R02:Incorporate a written procedure/checklist for both the truck driver and the employee to follow at the time of delivery and prior to the filling the tank.

R03:Within the maintenance program, include an annual inspection of all pressure relief valves.

R04:Within the delivery procedures, include an inspection of the paper work, checking to match the bill-of-loading with the invoice.

R05:Check manufacturer¿s recommendations regarding relief valve maintenance/replacement. (Some industry groups recommend replacement or recertification every five years).  Incorporate the finding in the maintenance program.

R06:	Determine the shut off mechanism for the pumps.  Check if they can be remotely shut down from the control room or by a switch outside the containment berm

R07:In the event that the system is

not running, consider closing the discharge valve.

R08:If an odor of ammonia is detected during the walk through, take note of it.  Keep a record of where it was detected; the odor may only last a few seconds and the location needs to be accurate.

R09:Consider installing insulation on the above ground piping.  Due to extreme temperatures, the insulation will help to prevent scolding. 

R10:Obtain safety equipment that employees should use (i.e. rubber gloves, hard hats, eye and skin protection).

R11:Determine disposal procedures for the aqueous ammonia in the event it spills into the containment tank and document this procedure.

R12:Conduct a final inspection with the Hazard Review Team once construction is complete.

R13:Conduct a seismic inspection of the system once construction is complete.
